awd_titl_txt: Pleistocene Paleointensity Record of Aleutian Island Volcanics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a geologic investigation aimed at furthering our understanding of the Earth's ancient magnetic field. The PI is  working with the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) in Anchorage, Alaska to collect lava flow samples from Tanaga Island in the Aleutian Island chain. Magnetic experiments on these lavas will allow the team to recover the strength of the Earth's ancient magnetic field in Alaska and use that information to evaluate the average behavior of the geomagnetic field over the last 500 thousand years. Paleomagnetic data (such as the paleointensity information collected as part of this project) play an important role in many geologic and geophysical applications, such as: performing plate tectonic reconstructions, determining the age of rock formations and timing of tectonic events, and developing models of the Earth's interior. This project will present the first high-quality paleointensity study of Alaskan lava flows, and will allow researchers to better understand how the geomagnetic field behaves at high northern latitudes. 

Effective analysis of ancient geomagnetic field structures requires the collection of global paleomagnetic data that are geographically and temporally distributed. Most published paleomagnetic data are from mid-latitudes, with relatively few studies targeting localities at equatorial and high latitudes (> 50°). A search of the online MagIC paleomagnetic database (http://earthreg.org/MAGIC) shows that only four studies are from Alaska, and none of them present any paleointensity data. This project will be the first high-quality paleointensity study in the region. The PI and students will sample volcanic material from 35 Pleistocene-age lava flows from Tanaga Island. All lava flows have been dated using 40Ar/39Ar geochronology methods by researchers with the U.S. Geological Survey. Paleointensity experiments will be conducted on all lavas, and the results will be compared to other high latitude data sets in northern and southern hemispheres. Evaluation of our intensity results will allow for new insights into the long-term regional behavior of the geomagnetic field in Alaska and the variability of the global field over time.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to evaluate the strength of the Earth's magnetic field in Alaska and Hawaii during the last few thousand years. The Earth's magnetic field strength and overall behavior changes over time, and the new data from Alaska and Hawaii will help researchers better constrain and understand the behavior of the magnetic field. This project was also intended to give young scientists research experience.

Volcanic samples from three volcanoes along the Alaska-Aleutian volcanic arc were gathered from existing collections. Preliminary results from two volcanoes, Tanaga and Akutan, were inconclusive due to poor experimental results. Future work on samples from these volcanoes may yield more reliable, and interpretable, results. Preliminary results from Tanaga and Akutan volcanoes were published as a poster presentation at the Geological Society of America 2016 Cordilleran Section meeting. Results from the third volcano, Aniakchak, provided reliable interpretations of the strength of the magnetic field over the last 2,300 years. Experimental results from Aniakchak were high-quality and had similar trends in field strength to existing models of the geomagnetic field but indicated that the existing models may overestimate the magnetic field strength at Aniakchak. These new results will help researchers better understand the behavior of the geomagnetic field in Alaska and improve future models. Results from the Aniakchak volcano study were published in October 2021 in a scientific journal article in the journal "Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems."

Volcanic samples from Hawaii were collected from the islands of Maui and Oahu. Experimental results from these samples were high-quality and were compared to previous results from the island of Hawaii to provide interpretations of the strength of the magnetic field for the last four million years (Ma). Preliminary results indicate that there are two distinct periods of field strength, a higher strength period between 0-1 Ma and a lower strength period between 1-4 Ma. Preliminary results from Hawaii were also compared to previous results from Iceland and Antarctica and indicate that paleointensity from these regions are consistent with the classic dipole model of the Earth's magnetic field. Preliminary results form this study were published as a poster presentation at the American Geophysical Union 2020 Fall Meeting. Final results will likely be published in the next year.

This project provided research opportunities to four undergraduate students and two graduate students, each of whom participated on different parts of the project. These young scientists learned how to collect samples in the field, how to conduct laboratory experiments, how to analyze data, and how to disseminate their findings to the scientific community. This project provided funds to enable several of the young scientists to travel to Alaska and Hawaii to collect samples and learn about the geologic, scientific, and cultural histories of those areas. These young scientists were key to the success of this project.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2021
Modified by: Geoffrey Cromwell
